title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 11 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Corinthians chapter 11 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 11 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Corinthians Chapter 11.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 11:3, who is the head of every man?
questions.correctAnswer: Christ
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that the head of every man is Christ.

questions.question: What should a man not do when praying or prophesying according to 1 Corinthians 11:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Cover his head
questions.explanation: Verse 4 says every man praying or prophesying having his head covered dishonours his head.

questions.question: What is the consequence for a woman praying or prophesying with her head uncovered according to 1 Corinthians 11:5?
questions.correctAnswer: She dishonours her head
questions.explanation: Verse 5 explains that a woman praying or prophesying with her head uncovered dishonours her head.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from 1 Corinthians 11:7: 'For a man indeed ought not to cover his head, forasmuch as he is the image and glory of ____.'
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states that man is the image and glory of God.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 11:8 says the man is of the woman.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 8 says the man is not of the woman, but the woman of the man.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 11:10, why ought the woman to have power on her head?
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the angels
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states the woman ought to have power on her head because of the angels.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 11:14 say nature teaches about a man with long hair?
questions.correctAnswer: It is a shame
questions.explanation: Verse 14 says nature teaches that if a man has long hair, it is a shame unto him.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 11:15, what is long hair to a woman?
questions.correctAnswer: A glory
questions.explanation: Verse 15 says that long hair is a glory to a woman and given as a covering.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 11:16 says the churches of God have a custom of contentiousness.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states that if any man seems contentious, there is no such custom in the churches of God.

questions.question: What does Paul praise the Corinthians for in 1 Corinthians 11:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Remembering him in all things
questions.explanation: Verse 2 praises the brethren for remembering Paul in all things and keeping the ordinances.

questions.question: What problem does Paul mention about the Corinthians coming together in 1 Corinthians 11:18?
questions.correctAnswer: Divisions among them
questions.explanation: Verse 18 states there are divisions among the Corinthians when they come together in church.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 11:20, what was not happening properly when they came together?
questions.correctAnswer: Eating the Lord's supper
questions.explanation: Verse 20 says that when they come together, it is not to eat the Lord’s supper properly.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 11:22 criticizes the Corinthians for despising the church of God and shaming those who have not.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 22 questions if they despise the church of God and shame those who have not, and Paul does not praise them for it.

questions.question: What did the Lord Jesus do the night He was betrayed according to 1 Corinthians 11:23?
questions.correctAnswer: Took bread
questions.explanation: Verse 23 says that the Lord Jesus took bread the night He was betrayed.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 11:27, who will be guilty of the body and blood of the Lord?
questions.correctAnswer: Whosoever eats and drinks unworthily
questions.explanation: Verse 27 states that whoever eats the bread and drinks the cup of the Lord unworthily is guilty of His body and blood.

medium.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 11 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Corinthians Chapter 11 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is confused about spiritual authority in family and church. Based on 1 Corinthians 11, what biblical truth would you share about headship?
options: Christ is the head of every man, the man is the head of the woman, and God is the head of Christ
The woman is the head of the man, and Christ is the head of God
God is the head of every man, and the man and woman share equal headship
The man is the head of God, and Christ is the head of the woman
questions.correctAnswer: Christ is the head of every man, the man is the head of the woman, and God is the head of Christ
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:3 clearly states the order of headship as Christ over man, man over woman, and God over Christ, teaching respect for divine authority and order in relationships.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 11 teach about humility and respect during prayer for men and women in the church?
options: Men should not cover their heads, but women should cover theirs when praying or prophesying
Both men and women should cover their heads equally during prayer
Men should cover their heads, but women should not
Neither men nor women need to cover their heads
questions.correctAnswer: Men should not cover their heads, but women should cover theirs when praying or prophesying
questions.explanation: Verses 4-7 explain that men dishonor their head (Christ) if they cover their heads while praying or prophesying, whereas women dishonor their head if they pray or prophesy with their heads uncovered, emphasizing humility and respect.

questions.question: A sister in Christ wonders about the significance of her hair during worship. What biblical insight from 1 Corinthians 11 would you provide?
options: Long hair is a glory to a woman and is given as a covering
Hair length has no spiritual significance
Short hair is preferable for women in worship
Women should shave their heads to show humility
questions.correctAnswer: Long hair is a glory to a woman and is given as a covering
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:14-15 teaches that nature itself shows long hair is a glory to a woman and serves as a covering, reinforcing the principle of modesty and honor in worship.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 11 counsel believers regarding the Lord's Supper and the attitude they should have?
options: Believers should examine themselves and partake worthily to avoid judgment
The Lord's Supper is just a social meal with no spiritual significance
It is acceptable to come hungry and compete for food during the Lord's Supper
Only the church leaders should partake of the Lord's Supper
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should examine themselves and partake worthily to avoid judgment
questions.explanation: Verses 27-29 teach that partaking unworthily brings guilt and judgment, so self-examination is necessary to honor Christ's sacrifice during the Lord's Supper.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with pride and division in their church fellowship. According to 1 Corinthians 11, what should they understand about unity and judgment?
options: There are divisions and heresies so that the approved may be revealed; self-judgment prevents harsher judgment
Division is encouraged to test faith
Heresies prove a church is unworthy of God's presence
Believers should ignore divisions and avoid judgment altogether
questions.correctAnswer: There are divisions and heresies so that the approved may be revealed; self-judgment prevents harsher judgment
questions.explanation: Verses 18-19 and 31-32 explain that divisions reveal those approved by God, and judging ourselves prevents condemnation, teaching humility and self-reflection to maintain unity.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 11 instruct believers to behave when coming together to eat the Lord's Supper?
options: Wait for one another and avoid selfishness to prevent condemnation
Eat quickly and individually without waiting
Bring extra food to share with outsiders only
Ignore others’ needs and focus on personal devotion
questions.correctAnswer: Wait for one another and avoid selfishness to prevent condemnation
questions.explanation: Verses 33-34 advise believers to wait for each other when eating, promoting fellowship and preventing selfishness that leads to condemnation.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 11, a man dishonors Christ when he prays or prophesies with his head covered.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:4 states that every man praying or prophesying with his head covered dishonors his head, which is Christ, emphasizing respect in worship.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 11 teaches that women should pray or prophesy with their heads uncovered as a sign of honor.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: According to 1 Corinthians 11:5-6, a woman praying or prophesying with her head uncovered dishonors her head and it is considered shameful, indicating the importance of head covering as a symbol of respect.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 1 Corinthians 11 teaches that the woman ought to have power on her head because of the ____.
questions.correctAnswer: angels
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states that a woman ought to have power on her head because of the angels, highlighting spiritual order and reverence in worship practices.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 11, what does the bread represent during the Lord's Supper?
options: The body of Christ, broken for believers
A symbol of fellowship among friends
A reminder of the manna in the wilderness
An offering to the church leaders
questions.correctAnswer: The body of Christ, broken for believers
questions.explanation: Verse 24 explains Jesus took bread, gave thanks, broke it, and said it was His body broken for us, teaching believers to remember His sacrifice.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 11 say about the new testament in the blood of Christ during the Lord's Supper?
options: The cup represents the new testament in Christ's blood, to be taken in remembrance of Him
The cup is a symbol of joy and celebration only
The cup is optional during the Lord's Supper
The cup represents the law given to Moses
questions.correctAnswer: The cup represents the new testament in Christ's blood, to be taken in remembrance of Him
questions.explanation: Verse 25 states Jesus took the cup and called it the new testament in His blood, instructing believers to drink it in remembrance of Him.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 11 describe the consequences of eating and drinking unworthily during the Lord's Supper?
options: One is guilty of the body and blood of the Lord and brings judgment upon themselves
There are no consequences; it is a personal matter
One gains spiritual strength without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: One is guilty of the body and blood of the Lord and brings judgment upon themselves
questions.explanation: Verses 27-29 warn that partaking unworthily brings guilt and judgment, including sickness and death, urging self-examination and reverence.

questions.question: A believer wants to understand how nature teaches about hair and shame in 1 Corinthians 11. What does the passage say?
options: If a man has long hair, it is shameful; if a woman has long hair, it is her glory
Both men and women should have short hair to avoid shame
Long hair is shameful for both men and women
Hair length has no bearing on shame or glory
questions.correctAnswer: If a man has long hair, it is shameful; if a woman has long hair, it is her glory
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 explain that nature teaches long hair is shameful for men but glorious for women, emphasizing gender distinctions in appearance as part of God's design.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 11 say about the custom regarding contentious men over head coverings in the churches of God?
options: There is no such custom in the churches of God
Contentious men are encouraged to cover their heads
All men must cover their heads to avoid contention
Contentious men should be excluded from worship
questions.correctAnswer: There is no such custom in the churches of God
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states that if anyone is contentious about head coverings, the churches of God have no such custom, underscoring unity in practice.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 11 encourage believers to approach ordinances and traditions that have been passed down?
options: Remember and keep the ordinances as delivered
Change ordinances according to personal preference
Ignore traditions as they are outdated
questions.correctAnswer: Remember and keep the ordinances as delivered
questions.explanation: Verse 2 praises the believers for remembering Paul in all things and keeping the ordinances as he delivered them, emphasizing obedience and faithfulness.

hard.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 11 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Corinthians Chapter 11.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 11:3, what is the hierarchical order of heads mentioned by Paul?
options: Man over woman, Christ over man, God over Christ
God over Christ, Christ over man, man over woman
Woman over man, Christ over God, man over Christ
Christ over God, man over woman, God over Christ
questions.correctAnswer: God over Christ, Christ over man, man over woman
questions.explanation: Paul explicitly states the order as 'the head of every man is Christ; and the head of the woman is the man; and the head of Christ is God' in 1 Corinthians 11:3, establishing a divine and social hierarchy.

questions.question: In the cultural context of 1 Corinthians 11, why is it considered dishonorable for a man to cover his head while praying or prophesying?
options: Because man is the image and glory of God
Because it shows humility before God
Because it was a Roman custom to pray uncovered
questions.correctAnswer: Because man is the image and glory of God
questions.explanation: Verse 7 explains that a man ought not to cover his head because he is the image and glory of God, indicating that uncovering the head honors that divine image.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 11:10 explain the reason a woman should have a covering on her head?
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the angels
questions.explanation: Paul states in 1 Corinthians 11:10 that 'the woman to have power on her head because of the angels,' suggesting a spiritual or heavenly rationale behind the practice.

questions.question: What does Paul mean by stating 'if a woman prayeth or prophesieth with her head uncovered, it is even all one as if she were shaven' (1 Corinthians 11:5)?
options: It is a sign of mourning
questions.correctAnswer: It is dishonoring her head
questions.explanation: Verse 5 explains that praying or prophesying uncovered dishonors her head, comparable to being shaven, which was culturally shameful.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 1 Corinthians 11:14, nature itself teaches that if a man has long hair, it is a ____ unto him.
questions.correctAnswer: Shame
questions.explanation: Paul appeals to natural law in verse 14, stating that long hair on a man is shameful, linking cultural norms with theological reasoning.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'the woman is the glory of the man' in 1 Corinthians 11:7 when considering Old Testament creation narratives?
options: It reflects the creation of woman from man’s rib in Genesis
It refers to the woman’s dominion over man
It is a metaphor for equality
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the creation of woman from man’s rib in Genesis
questions.explanation: Paul’s statement aligns with Genesis 2:21-23 where woman is created from man, establishing a typological connection between creation and social order.

questions.question: How does the instruction in 1 Corinthians 11:24-25 about the Lord’s Supper connect typologically to Old Testament covenant rituals?
options: It establishes the new covenant through Jesus’ body and blood
It replaces the Passover lamb with bread and wine
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes the new covenant through Jesus’ body and blood
questions.explanation: Verses 24-25 present the bread and cup as symbols of Christ’s body and blood, echoing covenant language from Jeremiah 31:31 about a new covenant.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 11:11-12, Paul teaches that men and women are interdependent in the Lord despite the hierarchical headship.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Paul affirms mutual dependence in verses 11-12, balancing the earlier hierarchy with a theological statement on unity in Christ.

questions.question: What critique does Paul offer about the Corinthians' conduct when coming together to eat the Lord's Supper in 1 Corinthians 11:20-22?
options: They are eating selfishly and some are getting drunk
They are ignoring the poor by giving alms
questions.correctAnswer: They are eating selfishly and some are getting drunk
questions.explanation: Verses 20-22 describe the Corinthians' divisive behavior, where some eat ahead and others get drunk, which dishonors the Lord’s Supper.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 11:27-29, what is the consequence of partaking in the Lord’s Supper unworthily?
options: Being guilty of the body and blood of the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Being guilty of the body and blood of the Lord
questions.explanation: Paul warns in these verses that unworthy participation brings guilt and condemnation because it shows a failure to discern the Lord’s body.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in 1 Corinthians 11:3 through the symmetrical ordering of headship: God, Christ, man, woman?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The verse structures the hierarchy in a chiastic pattern (A-B-B-A), emphasizing relational authority and dependence.

questions.question: How does Paul’s instruction on head coverings relate to Greco-Roman cultural practices of the 1st century?
options: Head coverings signified social status and propriety for women
Men always covered their heads in public
Both genders were expected to cover their heads
Head coverings were irrelevant in Greco-Roman culture
questions.correctAnswer: Head coverings signified social status and propriety for women
questions.explanation: In Greco-Roman society, women’s head coverings were markers of modesty and respectability, which Paul invokes to maintain order and honor in worship.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the phrase 'For as often as ye eat this bread, and drink this cup, ye do shew the Lord's death till he come' (1 Corinthians 11:26)?
options: The Lord’s Supper is a proclamation of Christ’s death and a foreshadowing of His return
It is a mere ritual with no symbolic meaning
It replaces baptism as the primary sacrament
It is a private act of devotion
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord’s Supper is a proclamation of Christ’s death and a foreshadowing of His return
questions.explanation: Verse 26 highlights the eschatological and memorial function of the Lord’s Supper, connecting it to Christ’s death and anticipated second coming.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 11:30-32, what is the purpose of the weakness, sickness, and death experienced by some believers in the Corinthian church?
options: They are chastened by the Lord to avoid condemnation with the world
They are punished by the community
They are signs of spiritual failure
They are unrelated to their conduct
questions.correctAnswer: They are chastened by the Lord to avoid condemnation with the world
questions.explanation: Paul explains that these sufferings are divine discipline meant to correct and prevent final condemnation, as stated in verses 30-32.

questions.question: Why does Paul admonish the Corinthians to 'judge in yourselves' whether it is proper for a woman to pray uncovered (1 Corinthians 11:13)?
options: To appeal to their own sense of propriety and reflection
questions.correctAnswer: To appeal to their own sense of propriety and reflection
questions.explanation: Verse 13 invites the Corinthians to thoughtful self-examination, reflecting the rhetorical style of Paul to engage conscience rather than impose external rules.

theological.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 11 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Corinthians Chapter 11 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 11, who is described as the head of every man?
questions.correctAnswer: Christ
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:3 states that the head of every man is Christ. This is consistent with the biblical teaching that Christ is the head of the church (Ephesians 1:22), and His authority extends over believers (Colossians 1:18).

questions.question: What reason does Paul give for men not covering their heads while praying or prophesying?
options: Because man is the glory of God
Because man is the image and glory of God
Because man is the head of woman
questions.correctAnswer: Because man is the image and glory of God
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 11:7, Paul explains that a man ought not to cover his head because he is the image and glory of God. This reflects the creation order given in Genesis 1:27, where man was made in God's image, and Psalm 8:5, which speaks of man's glory in creation.

questions.question: What does Paul say is the proper sign of authority or power on a woman's head?
questions.correctAnswer: A veil or covering
questions.explanation: According to 1 Corinthians 11:10, a woman ought to have power on her head because of the angels, which is traditionally understood as a sign of authority or submission manifested by a covering. This is consistent with cultural and theological understandings of honor and order in worship.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the relationship between man and woman in terms of origin?
options: Man is not of woman; woman is of man
Woman is not of man; man is of woman
Man and woman are created independently
Man and woman are equal in origin
questions.correctAnswer: Man is not of woman; woman is of man
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:8 states that the man is not of the woman, but the woman is of the man. This echoes the Genesis account where woman was created from man’s rib (Genesis 2:22), emphasizing the creation order and relational roles.

questions.question: What does Paul say is shameful for a woman if she prays or prophesies with her head uncovered?
options: It is like being dishonored publicly
questions.correctAnswer: It is like being shaven
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:5 explains that a woman praying or prophesying with her head uncovered dishonors her head, for it is as if she were shaven. This reflects cultural norms about modesty and propriety in worship, paralleling Old Testament calls for holiness (Leviticus 19:27).

questions.question: What does Paul say about the long hair of a man according to nature?
options: It is a glory to him
It is a shame to him
It is a sign of wisdom
It is a sign of strength
questions.correctAnswer: It is a shame to him
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 11:14, Paul states that nature teaches that if a man has long hair, it is a shame to him. This reflects cultural and theological understandings of gender distinctions rooted in creation (Genesis 1:27) and social order.

questions.question: What is said to be given to a woman for a covering according to 1 Corinthians 11?
questions.correctAnswer: Her hair
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:15 teaches that a woman's long hair is given to her for a covering, symbolizing glory and honor. This aligns with the principle of natural distinctions between genders as ordained in creation.

questions.question: Why does Paul reprimand the Corinthians for their conduct when coming together to eat the Lord's Supper?
options: They come together for the worse, not the better
They do not bring enough food
questions.correctAnswer: They come together for the worse, not the better
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:17 criticizes the Corinthians because their gatherings are not for improvement but for deterioration. This is consistent with Paul's call for orderly worship and mutual edification (1 Corinthians 14:40).

questions.question: What problem among the Corinthians is Paul partly believing when he hears of divisions?
questions.correctAnswer: There are heresies among them
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:18-19 shows that divisions and heresies were present so that those approved might be revealed. This highlights the reality of doctrinal testing within the church, consistent with warnings in Acts 20:29-30 and Jude 1:3-4.

questions.question: According to Paul, what is the consequence of eating the Lord’s Supper unworthily?
options: Guilt of the body and blood of the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Guilt of the body and blood of the Lord
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:27 warns that whoever eats the bread and drinks the cup unworthily is guilty of the body and blood of the Lord. This reflects the seriousness of partaking in the Lord’s Supper rightly, echoing warnings in Exodus 12:15 and Hebrews 10:29.

questions.question: What does Paul advise believers to do before eating the bread and drinking the cup?
questions.correctAnswer: Examine themselves
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:28 instructs believers to examine themselves before partaking of the bread and cup, emphasizing self-reflection and repentance. This aligns with biblical calls to holiness before God (Psalm 139:23-24; Lamentations 3:40).

questions.question: What does Paul say happens to many Corinthians because of unworthy eating and drinking?
options: Many are weak and sickly, and some sleep (die)
questions.correctAnswer: Many are weak and sickly, and some sleep (die)
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:30 states that many among them are weak, sickly, and some have died because of unworthy participation. This underscores the spiritual and physical consequences of disrespecting sacred ordinances, consistent with divine discipline (Hebrews 12:6).

questions.question: What does Paul say should be done when believers come together to eat in the church?
questions.correctAnswer: Tarry one for another
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 11:33, Paul advises believers to wait for one another when they come together to eat, promoting unity and order in the assembly. This teaching aligns with principles of mutual care and respect found in Romans 12:10 and Philippians 2:3.

questions.question: What does Paul say about eating at home if someone is hungry during the church gathering?
options: Let him eat at home so as not to bring condemnation
Let him eat in the church quietly
Let him fast until the next meeting
questions.correctAnswer: Let him eat at home so as not to bring condemnation
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:34 instructs that if anyone is hungry, they should eat at home to avoid coming together to judgment or condemnation. This promotes order and reverence in the Lord’s Supper, consistent with the call to holiness in worship (Isaiah 52:11).

questions.question: What is the significance of eating the bread and drinking the cup according to Paul?
options: Proclaiming the Lord's death until He comes
questions.correctAnswer: Proclaiming the Lord's death until He comes
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 11:26 teaches that eating the bread and drinking the cup is to show the Lord’s death until He returns. This is a proclamation of the gospel and a reminder of Christ’s atoning work, consistent with Luke 22:19-20 and Revelation 22:20.
